title: Stow on the Wold to Bourton on the Water Walk Route
gpx_url: http://gps-routes.co.uk/A55CD9/home.nsf/All/02612A57AEAE6955862585330050FD63/$FILE/Stow on the Wold to Bourton on the Water Walk.gpx

images.title: User: (WT-shared) Pieter at  wts wikivoyage / CC BY-SA (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0)
images.caption: A scene in the center of Bourton-on-the-Water

images.title: Graham Horn / Hidden Lower Slaughter
images.caption: Hidden Lower Slaughter. Less than 400 yards from the bit of Lower Slaughter that the tourists visit, but in a different world. This is Lower Slaughter cricket pitch with a few Cotswold stone houses behind that in any other village would receive at least a second glance.

images.title: Graham Horn / On the Macmillan Way
images.caption: On the Macmillan Way. The Macmillan Way climbs up from Lower Slaughter and continues in a south westerly direction on a good bridleway. Going against the grain of the land there are a lot of small climbs and descents; here we are near the crest of one such small ridge.

images.title: The Wardens' Way [2] by Michael Dibb, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Wardens' Way. A view of this path near Lower Slaughter.

images.title: Graham Horn / On the Gloucestershire Way
images.caption: On the Gloucestershire Way. The Gloucestershire Way soon leaves Stow town centre on this path on the west side of the A429. It is also a convenient route for Macmillan Way walkers who have diverted to stay in Stow overnight; not strictly on route but avoids a longer section of road walking. When you are halfway between Lincolnshire and Dorset the odd diversion won't make much difference.

images.title: Michael Dibb / Hyde Mill
images.caption: Hyde Mill. Situated spanning the River Dikler, the mill is seen from the Macmillan Way long distance path.

description: This linear walk joins these two picturesque Cotswolds village using a series of waymarked footpaths. The route runs for a distance of just over 4 miles, descending from the higher village of Stow on the Wold to the tourist honeypot of Bourton on the Water . On the way there's old mills, river views, rolling hills and a visit to the popular village of Lower Slaughter too. The route makes use of two of the waymarked trails which run through the area in the form of the Gloucestershire Way and the Windrush Way . As such it's generally a good footpath and well signposted throughout. In Lower Slaughter you could take a short detour from the route and try The Slaughters Walk which takes you between the two neighbouring villages on the River Eye.
